section.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
section.subsection:
Energy Change of a Thermally Insualted System
To get oriented with the energy considerations in a thermodynamic system, let us consider a simple system of a gas contained in a cylinder with movable piston as in . Suppose the cylinder and piston are thermally insulated from the environment.
The gas is compressed in a thermally insulated environment with positive work on the gas by the spring force.
⁨
Suppose you balance the force of gas on the piston by force F from a compressed spring that has the other end fixed. Suppose the force on the piston by the spring is infinitesimally larger than the force by the gas so that the piston moves by a distance \Delta x into the gas, corresponding to change in volume \Delta V. The work done by the spring force will be
W = F\Delta x.
This will be the energy lost by the spring,
\Delta U_\text{spring} = - W,
which is the amount of energy gained by the gas in expansion.
\Delta E_\text{gas} = W = -p\Delta V.
We think of the gas as the thermodynamic system and the spring as environment and state this observation as a conservation of energy as
\Delta E_\text{gas} = \text{Energy exchanged with environment.}
Here, we saw the mechanism of exchange of energy through performance of a mechanical work.

subsection.title: Energy Change of a Fixed-Volume System
subsection.p: In the above qwe saw energy change of a thermally insulated system. Let us now consider a situation where the system is in thermal contact. To isolate the thermal effect, we examine a gas in a rigid container which is a good conductor of heat.

Suppose the gas is initially at temperature T. The gas is in thermal equilibrium with a water bath also at temperature T. You will find that the energy of the gas will not change. But, if you heat the water bath, as the temperature of the bath increases, the temperature of the gas will also increase. But since volume of the gas did not change, the energy change of the gas is not by a mechanical work, but by some other mechanism. We call this mechanism of energy transfer, heat.

If you look at the heating process microscopically, with increasing temperature, the molecules of water bath have higher momentum, and when they collide with the container, they transfer some of the energy to the container molecules, which in turn transfer energy to the gas molecules.
We denote energy exchange by this mechanism by letter Q or Q_{if}, where the subscript refers to the process.

subsection.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
subsection.p:
In the last two subsections, we identified two mechanisms by which energy of a thermodynamic system can change - (1) work W done by the enevironment and (2) energy flow Q due to a temperature difference across a thermal contact. Summing these two mechanisms gives us the statement of First Law of Thermodynamics.
\Delta E = Q + W.
Notice that we need to be careful with the signs - Q is positive if temperature of the system is less than that of environment and W is positive if positive work is done on the system.
